name: 1586_C. Omkar and Determination
description:
The problem statement looms below, filling you with determination.

Consider a grid in which some cells are empty and some cells are filled. Call a cell in this grid exitable if, starting at that cell, you can exit the grid by moving up and left through only empty cells. This includes the cell itself, so all filled in cells are not exitable. Note that you can exit the grid from any leftmost empty cell (cell in the first column) by going left, and from any topmost empty cell (cell in the first row) by going up.

Let's call a grid determinable if, given only which cells are exitable, we can exactly determine which cells are filled in and which aren't.

You are given a grid a of dimensions n × m , i. e. a grid with n rows and m columns. You need to answer q queries (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5). Each query gives two integers x_1, x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m) and asks whether the subgrid of a consisting of the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX

prompt:
The problem statement looms below, filling you with determination.

Consider a grid in which some cells are empty and some cells are filled. Call a cell in this grid exitable if, starting at that cell, you can exit the grid by moving up and left through only empty cells. This includes the cell itself, so all filled in cells are not exitable. Note that you can exit the grid from any leftmost empty cell (cell in the first column) by going left, and from any topmost empty cell (cell in the first row) by going up.

Let's call a grid determinable if, given only which cells are exitable, we can exactly determine which cells are filled in and which aren't.

You are given a grid a of dimensions n × m , i. e. a grid with n rows and m columns. You need to answer q queries (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5). Each query gives two integers x_1, x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m) and asks whether the subgrid of a consisting of the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable. Ensure your solution is efficient to handle the upper limits of inputs smoothly.

Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX

from typing import List
## main.py

import numpy as np

def preprocess_grid(grid: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the exitability of each cell.

    Args:
        grid (np.ndarray): The grid with cells marked as 'X' for filled and '.' for empty.

    Returns:
        np.ndarray: A 2D array indicating whether each cell is exitable.
    """
    n, m = grid.shape
    exitability = np.zeros((n, m), dtype=bool)

    # First row and first column initialization
    for i in range(n):
        if grid[i, 0] == '.':
            exitability[i, 0] = True
        else:
            break

    for j in range(m):
        if grid[0, j] == '.':
            exitability[0, j] = True
        else:
            break

    # Fill the exitability array
    for i in range(1, n):
        for j in range(1, m):
            if grid[i, j] == '.':
                exitability[i, j] = exitability[i-1, j] or exitability[i, j-1]

    return exitability

def is_subgrid_determinable(exitability: np.ndarray, x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Check if the subgrid is determinable based on exitability information.

    Args:
        exitability (np.ndarray): The exitability array of the grid.
        x1 (int): The starting column index of the subgrid.
        x2 (int): The ending column index of the subgrid.

    Returns:
        str: "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, "NO" otherwise.
    """
    n = exitability.shape[0]
    for j in range(x1, x2):
        for i in range(1, n):
            if exitability[i, j] and not exitability[i-1, j]:
                return "NO"
            if not exitability[i, j] and exitability[i-1, j]:
                return "NO"
    return "YES"

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    exitability = preprocess_grid(grid)
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_subgrid_determinable(exitability, x1-1, x2-1)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

import numpy as np

def preprocess_grid(grid: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the exitability of each cell.

    Args:
        grid (np.ndarray): The grid with 'X' for filled cells and '.' for empty cells.

    Returns:
        np.ndarray: A 2D numpy array indicating exitability with True for exitable cells and False otherwise.
    """
    n, m = grid.shape
    exitability = np.full((n, m), False)

    # Determine exitability from top row and left column
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i, j] == '.':
                if i == 0 or j == 0 or exitability[i-1, j] or exitability[i, j-1]:
                    exitability[i, j] = True

    return exitability

def is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid: np.ndarray, x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Check if a subgrid is determinable based on exitability information.

    Args:
        exitability_grid (np.ndarray): The preprocessed exitability grid.
        x1 (int): The starting column index of the subgrid (1-based).
        x2 (int): The ending column index of the subgrid (1-based).

    Returns:
        str: 'YES' if the subgrid is determinable, 'NO' otherwise.
    """
    # Convert 1-based index to 0-based index for numpy array slicing
    x1 -= 1
    x2 -= 1

    # Check if all columns in the subgrid have at least one exitable cell
    for j in range(x1, x2 + 1):
        if not np.any(exitability_grid[:, j]):
            return "NO"
    return "YES"

def main():
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Preprocess the grid
    exitability_grid = preprocess_grid(grid)

    # Output interface
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid, x1, x2)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def preprocess_exitability(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[List[bool]]:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the exitability of each cell."""
    exitable = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
    
    # First row and first column are trivially exitable if they are empty
    for i in range(n):
        if grid[i][0] == '.':
            exitable[i][0] = True
        else:
            break
    
    for j in range(m):
        if grid[0][j] == '.':
            exitable[0][j] = True
        else:
            break
    
    # Fill the rest of the exitable grid
    for i in range(1, n):
        for j in range(1, m):
            if grid[i][j] == '.' and (exitable[i-1][j] or exitable[i][j-1]):
                exitable[i][j] = True
    
    return exitable

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the subgrid specified by each query is determinable."""
    exitable = preprocess_exitability(n, m, grid)
    prefix_sum = [[0] * (m + 1) for _ in range(n + 1)]
    
    # Build prefix sum array for filled cells
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            prefix_sum[i+1][j+1] = prefix_sum[i+1][j] + prefix_sum[i][j+1] - prefix_sum[i][j] + (1 if grid[i][j] == 'X' else 0)
    
    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        determinable = True
        for i in range(n):
            if exitable[i][x1-1] and not exitable[i][x2-1]:
                determinable = False
                break
            if prefix_sum[i+1][x2] - prefix_sum[i+1][x1-1] > 0:
                determinable = False
                break
        
        if determinable:
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")
    
    return results

# Input interface

import numpy as np

def preprocess_grid(grid: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the exitability of each cell.

    Args:
        grid (np.ndarray): The grid with filled ('X') and empty ('.') cells.

    Returns:
        np.ndarray: A grid indicating exitability of each cell ('E' for exitable, 'N' for non-exitable).
    """
    n, m = grid.shape
    exitability_grid = np.full((n, m), 'N', dtype=str)

    # First row and first column are exitable if they are empty
    for i in range(n):
        if grid[i, 0] == '.':
            exitability_grid[i, 0] = 'E'
        else:
            break

    for j in range(m):
        if grid[0, j] == '.':
            exitability_grid[0, j] = 'E'
        else:
            break

    # Fill the rest of the exitability grid
    for i in range(1, n):
        for j in range(1, m):
            if grid[i, j] == '.' and (exitability_grid[i-1, j] == 'E' or exitability_grid[i, j-1] == 'E'):
                exitability_grid[i, j] = 'E'

    return exitability_grid

def is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid: np.ndarray, x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Check if the subgrid is determinable based on the exitability information.

    Args:
        exitability_grid (np.ndarray): The grid indicating exitability of each cell.
        x1 (int): Starting column index of the subgrid.
        x2 (int): Ending column index of the subgrid.

    Returns:
        str: "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, "NO" otherwise.
    """
    n = exitability_grid.shape[0]
    for j in range(x1, x2):
        for i in range(1, n):
            if exitability_grid[i, j] == 'E' and exitability_grid[i-1, j+1] == 'E':
                return "NO"
    return "YES"

def main():
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Output interface
    exitability_grid = preprocess_grid(grid)
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid, x1-1, x2-1)  # Adjust for zero-based index
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

import numpy as np

def preprocess_grid(grid: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the exitability of each cell.

    Args:
        grid (np.ndarray): The input grid with 'X' for filled and '.' for empty cells.

    Returns:
        np.ndarray: A 2D array indicating the exitability of each cell.
    """
    n, m = grid.shape
    exitability_grid = np.zeros((n, m), dtype=bool)

    # Traverse the grid to determine exitability
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i, j] == '.':
                if i == 0 or j == 0:
                    exitability_grid[i, j] = True
                else:
                    exitability_grid[i, j] = exitability_grid[i-1, j] or exitability_grid[i, j-1]

    return exitability_grid

def is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid: np.ndarray, x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Check if the subgrid is determinable based on exitability information.

    Args:
        exitability_grid (np.ndarray): The preprocessed exitability grid.
        x1 (int): The starting column index of the subgrid (1-based).
        x2 (int): The ending column index of the subgrid (1-based).

    Returns:
        str: "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, "NO" otherwise.
    """
    # Convert 1-based index to 0-based index
    x1 -= 1
    x2 -= 1

    # Check for transitions between exitable and non-exitable cells
    for j in range(x1, x2):
        if np.any(exitability_grid[:, j] != exitability_grid[:, j + 1]):
            return "NO"
    return "YES"

def main():
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    exitability_grid = preprocess_grid(grid)

    # Output results for each query
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid, x1, x2)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if subgrids specified by queries are determinable.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each specifying a range of columns.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of "YES" or "NO" for each query indicating if the subgrid is determinable.
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to find transitions between filled and empty cells
    transitions = [0] * (m - 1)
    
    for row in range(1, n):
        for col in range(m - 1):
            if grid[row][col] == 'X' and grid[row - 1][col + 1] == '.':
                transitions[col] = 1

    # Precompute prefix sums for transitions to quickly answer queries
    prefix_sum = [0] * (m - 1)
    prefix_sum[0] = transitions[0]
    for i in range(1, m - 1):
        prefix_sum[i] = prefix_sum[i - 1] + transitions[i]

    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        # Convert 1-based index to 0-based index
        x1 -= 1
        x2 -= 1

        # Check if there are any transitions in the range [x1, x2-1]
        if x1 == x2 - 1:
            # Single column, always determinable
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            if prefix_sum[x2 - 1] - (prefix_sum[x1] if x1 > 0 else 0) == 0:
                results.append("YES")
            else:
                results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Output results
    results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """
    Determines if subgrids specified by queries are determinable based on exitability of cells.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings, where 'X' is filled and '.' is empty.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each query is a tuple (x1, x2) representing the columns.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of "YES" or "NO" for each query indicating if the subgrid is determinable.
    """
    # Step 1: Preprocess the grid to determine exitability of each cell
    exitable = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
    
    # Mark exitable cells
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == '.':
                if i == 0 or j == 0 or exitable[i-1][j] or exitable[i][j-1]:
                    exitable[i][j] = True

    # Step 2: Use a prefix sum array to efficiently determine determinability
    non_determinable_transitions = [0] * m
    
    # Mark transitions from exitable to non-exitable cells
    for i in range(1, n):
        for j in range(1, m):
            if exitable[i][j] and not exitable[i-1][j] and not exitable[i][j-1]:
                non_determinable_transitions[j] += 1

    # Step 3: For each query, check if the subgrid is determinable
    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        if sum(non_determinable_transitions[x1:x2]) == 0:
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if subgrid is determinable based on exitable cells.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each query is a tuple of two integers.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each query, "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, otherwise "NO".
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to determine exitable cells using a prefix sum array
    prefix_sum = [0] * m
    for i in range(1, n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == 'X' and grid[i-1][j] == '.':
                prefix_sum[j] = 1

    # Accumulate prefix sums to determine connectivity
    for j in range(1, m):
        prefix_sum[j] += prefix_sum[j-1]

    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        # Check if there is a break in connectivity in the subgrid
        if prefix_sum[x2-1] - prefix_sum[x1-1] == 0:
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Call the function and print results
    results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """
    Determines if subgrids specified by queries are determinable based on the grid's exitable cells.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings, where 'X' is a filled cell and '.' is an empty cell.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each specifying a range of columns to check for determinability.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each query, "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, otherwise "NO".
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to find non-determinable transitions
    non_determinable = [False] * (m - 1)
    
    for row in range(1, n):
        for col in range(1, m):
            if grid[row][col] == 'X' and grid[row - 1][col - 1] == '.':
                non_determinable[col - 1] = True
    
    # Prepare results for each query
    results = []
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        # Check if there is any non-determinable transition within the specified column range
        if any(non_determinable[x1 - 1:x2 - 1]):
            results.append("NO")
        else:
            results.append("YES")
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]
    
    # Output interface
    results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

        def preprocess_exitability(grid):
            # Use numpy to efficiently determine exitability of each cell
            import numpy as np
            n, m = len(grid), len(grid[0])
            exitability = np.full((n, m), False)
            
            # Determine exitability from top row and left column
            for i in range(n):
                for j in range(m):
                    if grid[i][j] == '.':
                        if i == 0 or j == 0 or exitability[i-1][j] or exitability[i][j-1]:
                            exitability[i][j] = True
            
            return exitability

        def is_determinable(exitability, x1, x2):
            # Check if subgrid is determinable based on exitability information
            for j in range(x1-1, x2):
                if not np.all(exitability[:, j]):
                    return "NO"
            return "YES"

        # Example usage:
        grid = [
            "..XXX",
            "...X.",
            "...X.",
            "...X."
        ]

    Explanation: A cell is exitable if you can move up and left through only empty cells to exit the grid. Filled cells are not exitable.

    'determinable'
    Explanation: A grid is determinable if, given the exitable cells, you can exactly determine which cells are filled and which aren't.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    '1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5': Indicates the number of queries can range from 1 to 200,000.
    Explanation: This means the solution must efficiently handle up to 200,000 queries.

    '1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6': Indicates the grid dimensions constraints.
    Explanation: The grid can have up to 1,000,000 rows and columns, but the total number of cells cannot exceed 1,000,000.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    - Preprocess the grid to identify transitions between filled and empty cells.
    - Create a list to store the first occurrence of a non-determinable transition between columns.
    - For each query, check if there is any non-determinable transition within the specified column range.
    - Return "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, otherwise return "NO".

# [edge case]
    Input:
    1 1
    .
    1
    1 1
    Output:
    YES
    Explanation: A single empty cell is trivially determinable.

    Input:
    2 2
    ..
    ..
    1
    1 2
    Output:
    YES
    Explanation: All cells are empty, making the entire grid determinable.

    Input:
    2 2
    XX
    XX
    1
    1 2
    Output:
    NO
    Explanation: All cells are filled, making it impossible to determine exitability.

The solution must efficiently handle large grid sizes and high query counts, ensuring that each query is processed quickly and accurately. The output should be clear and easy to interpret, with a focus on performance optimization.
requirement pool:

- Accurate determination of subgrid determinability

We will use a preprocessing step to determine the exitable cells efficiently. By using a prefix sum array, we can quickly check if a subgrid is determinable. This approach will allow us to handle large grid sizes and high query counts efficiently. The prefix sum will help in determining the connectivity of exitable cells across columns.

# [core concept]
    'exitable'
    Explanation: An exitable cell is one from which you can exit the grid by moving up or left through only empty cells. Filled cells are not exitable.

    'determinable'
    Explanation: A grid is determinable if, given the exitable cells, you can exactly determine which cells are filled and which aren't.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    No explicit phrase showing quantity relationship

# [degree adverb] 
    No explicit degree adverb

# [code logic]
    1. Preprocess the grid to determine exitable cells using a prefix sum array.
    2. For each query, check the connectivity of exitable cells across the specified columns.
    3. If there is a break in connectivity (i.e., a filled cell interrupts the path of exitable cells), the subgrid is not determinable.
    4. Return "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, otherwise return "NO".

# [edge case] 
    Query: 1 1 = YES
    Explanation: The subgrid consists of only one column, which is determinable as there are no filled cells interrupting the path.

    Query: 1 5 = NO
    Explanation: The entire grid is queried, and there are multiple configurations that can produce the same exitability grid, making it non-determinable.

    Query: 2 4 = YES
    Explanation: The subgrid from columns 2 to 4 is determinable as there is a clear path of exitable cells without interruption.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The preprocessing step with prefix sum array will efficiently handle connectivity checks for any subgrid query.
examples:
Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX
